Key Laboratory of Biomass Chemical Engineering of Ministry of Education, Department of Chemistry, Zhejiang University Hangzhou 310028 China Selective hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanone is a vital step in the manufacture of fiber (nylon), which is currently carried out over expensive Pd catalyst with low productivity. In this work, a series of Ru-promoted Pd catalysts were synthesized in a facile microwave-assisted method and tested in the hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanone. It was found that small amount of Ru in Ru-Pd alloy can increase the conversion of phenol obviously without loss of cyclohexanone selectivity. The selectivity of cyclohexanone over Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP remained higher than 99%, while the conversion of phenol increased from 20.5% (over Pd5/ZrHP) to 97.9% at 100 °C and 1 MPa. And the highest turnover frequency (TOF) of surface metal in Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP at 100 °C and 2 MPa reached 1605 h−1. Characterization results revealed that the addition of Ru can improve the dispersion of Ru-Pd alloy and enhance its electron density. In addition, the activated hydrogen on Ru-Pd alloy and acid sites in ZrHP played a synergistic effect for the selective formation of cyclohexanone from phenol. Graphical Abstract A series of small amount Ru-promoted Pd catalysts on the surface of ZrHP (RuxPdy/ZrHP) were prepared in a facile microwave-assisted method and Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP was extremely active and selective for the hydrogenation of phenol. ga1 Keywords Phenol Hydrogenation Cyclohexanone Ru-Pd alloy ZrHP Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Cyclohexanone is an important precursor and intermediate in the manufacture of nylon, and millions of tons of cyclohexanone are produced annually. Up to now, most cyclohexanone are manufactured via the oxidation of cyclohexane with homogenous cobalt catalysts in hot acetic acid solution. But this process involves radicals and the intermediacy of hydroperoxide formation [1]. Alternatively, cyclohexanone can be synthesized via selective hydrogenation of phenol (see Eq. (1)) [2]. (1) C6H5OH + 2 H2 → (CH2)5CO (ΔG = ̶ 26·50 kJ/mol, 100 °C) (2) C6H5OH + 3 H2 → (CH2)5CHOH (ΔG = ̶ 55·31 kJ/mol, 100 °C) Unfortunately, the formation of cyclohexanol is more favorable during hydrogenation of phenol (see Eq. (2)), and cyclohexanol becomes the dominant product under high temperature or high conversion level of phenol [3–5]. On the surface of SiO2 and TiO2 supported Rh catalysts, Zhang et al. found that cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone formed simultaneously even at the beginning of reaction. And the initial selectivity of cyclohexanone increased only on enlarged Rh particles with a cost of decreased conversion of phenol (at phenol/Rh mole ratio = 100/1) [6]. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations also indicated that the activation energy of cyclohexanol formation from cyclohexanone was significantly lower on Pd {111} surface compared to those on {100} surface [5]. And it was popularly recommended that those low coordination edge and step sites should be blocked in order to depress the formation of cyclohexanol [1,6,7]. In the past decade, many kinds of catalysts were developed in order to increase the selectivity of cyclohexanone [8–15]. Among them, supported palladium (Pd) was the most popularly reported catalyst because the dissociation of phenol to phenoxy is both thermodynamically and kinetically favored on the surface of Pd, which could promote the formation of cyclohexanone [16–18]. At the same time, a lot of newly developed materials with multi-functional groups were also tested as the support of Pd nanoparticles (NPs) in order to enhance its performance [1,3,4,14–19]. Apart from Pd, Pt [13,20–22], and Ni [12,23,24] based catalysts have also been tried for the hydrogenation of phenol. But these metals are more favorable for the deep hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanol [20] or cycloalkanes [23,24]. Recently, Zhang et al. disclosed that a 3D structured Ru@NaX is capable for the selective hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanone because of peripheral X-zeolite skeleton can prevent the deep hydrogenation of cyclohexanone [25]. Meanwhile, it was reported that hydrogenation of phenol proceeded quickly on those catalysts with strong acid sites [3,7,21,26,27]. This increased activity was attributed to that acid sites could weaken the adsorption of hydrogen and phenol on the catalyst, which results in a decrease in the activation energy for addition of adsorbed H from metal to phenol [7,21]. Theoretical calculation further indicated that Lewis acid sites can inhibit the further hydrogenation of cyclohexanone to cyclohexanol [27] and Brønsted acid sites could facilitate the isomerization of cyclohexanol to cyclohexanone [28]. Zirconium hydrogen phosphate (ZrHP) is an acidic, inorganic cation exchangeable material with the formula of Zr(HPO4)2·H2O [29–32], which possesses plenty and adjustable Brønsted/Lewis acid sites. And these acid sites can generate synergistic effects with metal particles on its surface [33–37]. In this work, a series of small amount Ru-promoted Pd catalysts on the surface of ZrHP (Ru x Pdy/ZrHP) were prepared in a facile routine and tested in the selective hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanone. The structures of these catalysts were characterized and discussed with its performance. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials ZrOCl2·8 H2O (99.0%), H3PO4 (85%), PdCl2 (99.0%), RuCl3 (99.0%), ethylene glycol ((HOCH2)2) (99.9%), cyclohexane (C6H14) (99.9%), ethanol (C2H6O) (99.7%), phenol (C6H6O) (99.9%),o-cresol (C7H8O) (99%), m-cresol (C7H8O) (99%), p-cresol (C7H8O) (99%), 1,2-benzenediol (C6H6O2) (99.8%), 1,3-benzenediol (C6H6O2) (99.8%), and 1,4-benzenediol (C6H6O2) (99.8%) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China). 2-chlorophenol (C6H5ClO) (98%), 3-chlorophenol (C6H5ClO) (98%) and 4-chlorophenol (C6H5ClO) (98%) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (Shanghai, China). All these chemicals are analytically pure and they were used directly without further purification. 2.2 Catalysts preparation ZrHP was synthesized in a rapid microwave-assisted method. In a typical experiment, 0.016 mol ZrOCl2∙8 H2O and 6 mL 8 M H3PO4 were dissolved in deionized water (50 mL). This mixture was stirred for 90 min under room temperature and then reacted in a WBFY-201 microwave reactor (1100 W, Kenuo, China) at 150 °C for 20 min. After that, the mixture was cooled in ice water, and solid product was separated via centrifugation, washed with deionized water until neutral and free of Cl‾. Finally, the white powder was dried in vacuum at 80 °C for overnight and calcined at 200 °C for 4 h with a heating rate of 2 °C/min. Ru x Pdy/ZrHP catalysts were also synthesized in microwave-assisted method. Typically, 0.4 g ZrHP, appropriate amount of PdCl2 and RuCl3 were dispersed in 40 mL ethylene glycol. This mixture was further stirred for 90 min under room temperature and then heated in microwave reactor at 120 °C for 2 min. After being cooled to room temperature, the solid product was separated via centrifugation, washed with water and ethanol until free of Cl‾. Finally, the prepared catalyst was stored in ethanol for further using. In all prepared catalysts, the total loading amount of Ru + Pd was controlled to 5 wt% of the support. And these preparation procedures were diagrammatically presented in Scheme 1. These catalysts were denoted as RuxPdy/ZrHP, where “x” and “y” represent the content of loaded Ru and Pd in feed, respectively. The real content of Ru and Pd in the prepared catalyst (RuxPdy/ZrHP) was detected with inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES; Thermo Elemental IRIS Intrepid) and these data were summarized in Table 1. Reference catalysts with the same loading amount of Ru0.15Pd4.85 (5 wt% of the support) on MgO, CaO, SiO2, XC-72, Al2O3 and HBEA (Si/Al=25) were prepared in the similar procedures as Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP, and these procedures were addressed in supplementary material section. 2.3 Characterizations X-ray Diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a Rigaku SmartLab diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm) at 40 kV, 180 mA and a step of 0.02°. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured using an ASAP 2010 analyzer (Micromeritics), all samples were pretreated in vacuum at 200 °C for 4 h. The surface area of these samples was calculated using Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method according to the adsorption data and pore size distribution was obtained using Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on a Kratos Axis Ultra DLD system under a base pressure of 10−9 Torr. A monochromatic Al Kα (1486.6 eV) radiation source was applied and C 1 s (with the binding energy of 284.8 eV) was used for calibration. Temperature-programmed desorption of H2 (H2-TPD) was obtained on an online quadrupole mass spectrometer (OmniStarTM, GSD301, Switzerland). Sample (0.1 g) was first pretreated at 400 °C in Ar flow for 1 h, then cooled to 50 °C. After that, the sample was exposed to 10% H2/N2 for 30 min with a flow rate of 30 mL/min, and the physical adsorbed H2 was eliminated with Ar for 2 h at 50 °C. Finally, temperature-programmed desorption was conducted with a ramping of 10 °C/min to 350 °C. Hydrogen in effluent (m/e=2) was detected and recorded as a function of temperature. High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images were recorded on a JEOL-2020AF microscopy at 200 kV accelerate voltage. Spherical aberration-corrected transmission electron microscope (AC-TEM) images were observed on an FEI Titan G2 80–200 ChemiSTEM operating at 200 kV. Pyridine adsorption Fourier-transform infrared (Py-IR) spectra were obtained on Tensor 27 (Bruker, Germany) using self-supporting wafers of approximately 20 mg (1.3 cm diameter). Prior to the measurements, the wafers were pretreated under vacuum at 300 °C for 1 h inside a home-built IR cell with ZnSe windows, exposed to pyridine at 150 °C, and then evacuated at the same temperature to remove the physisorbed pyridine. IR spectra were collected at 150 °C (32 scans with a resolution of 4 cm−1). 2.4 Catalytic reaction Hydrogenation of phenol was carried out in a stainless-steel autoclave (50 mL) with a Teflon inner layer. In a typical run, 0.1 g catalyst and controlled amount of phenol were dispersed in 20 mL cyclohexane. The autoclave was sealed, flushed with purified H2 for 5 times and pressurized to desired pressure. And then, it was heated in an oil bath to the required temperature and the reaction was timed under vigorously stirring (1000 rpm). After reaction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature and reaction mixture was centrifuged to separate solid catalyst from liquid. Liquid phase was analyzed using a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu, 14B) equipped with a 30 m capillary column (DB-WAX 52CB, USA) and a flame ionization detector. All detected products were confirmed by GC-MS (Agilent 6890–5973 N). Solid catalyst was washed with cyclohexane, dried under vacuum at 40 °C for 6 h and weighed before next recycle. The conversion of phenol and selectivity for cyclohexanone were calculated as follows: Conversion ( % ) = Phenol added − mol − Phenol remain − mol Phenol added − mol × 100 % Selectivity ( % ) = Cyclohexanone formed − mol Phenol added − mol − Phenol remain − mol × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts XRD patterns of RuxPdy/ZrHP catalysts are presented in Fig. 1. It is confirmed that ZrHP could be synthesized in a microwave-assisted method, and those peaks at 2θ = 20.2°, 25.0°and 34.1° could be attributed to the diffraction of (110), (112) and (020) plane of ZrHP (PDF#00–022–1022), respectively. Apart from ZrHP, the characteristic diffraction peaks of metallic Pd (PDF#00–088–2335) appeared at 2θ = 40.0°, 46.5° and 68.1° in monometallic Pd5/ZrHP catalyst. It is interesting to note that the intensity of these peaks decreases continuously with the increasing amount of Ru in RuxPdy/ZrHP catalysts, and the diffraction peak of (111) plane of Pd or Ru-Pd alloy shifts to low angle (see Fig. 1(b)). According to the half-width of the diffraction peak at ∼40°, the calculated crystalline size of Pd or Ru-Pd alloy in those catalysts decrease from 2.3 to 1.6 nm (see Table 1). These results indicate that the addition of Ru can promote the dispersion of Pd or Ru-Pd alloy in RuxPdy/ZrHP, which might be contributed to the formation of Ru-Pd alloy as the radius of Ru (126 pm) is smaller than that of Pd (137 pm) [38–42]. The formation of well dispersed Ru-Pd alloy in RuxPdy/ZrHP could be attributed to that microwave method can provide a uniform nucleation environment, and ethylene glycol can provide the reducing environment and/or act as a stabilizer of formed particles [43]. At the same time, the composition of alloy could be controlled easily because the utilization of metal ions was higher via microwave irradiation [44], and microwave reduction can protect the acid sites of ZrHP (avoiding the usage of alkli ion during reduction process). N2 adsorption-desorption isothermals of RuxPdy/ZrHP are shown in Fig. 2. It is found that the adsorption and desorption curves of these catalysts are pseudo type IV with a hysteresis at high P/P 0 (0.85–0.99), indicating that they have a layered structure. And the calculated surface area (15.6–22.9 m2/g) and pore volume (0.40–0.45 cm3/g) of RuxPdy/ZrHP catalysts increased slightly compared with that of pure support (ZrHP) (5.9 m2/g and 0.29 cm3/g see Table 1) because of partial Pd or Ru-Pd alloy particles might load into the layered structure of ZrHP. Fig. 3 exhibits the XPS survey of RuxPdy/ZrHP catalysts and the calculated surface content of each element are summarized in Table 2. It is found that the surface content of Ru and Pd is higher than their bulk composition (see Table 1), indicating that Ru-Pd alloy disperse highly on the surface and/or interlayer of ZrHP. At the same time, the binding energy of Pd 3d in Pd5/ZrHP catalyst could be deconvoluted into two pairs of double peaks (see Fig. 3(b)). The pair peaks at 334.96 eV (Pd 3d 5/2 ) and 340.25 eV (Pd 3d 3/2 ) are assigned to metallic Pd, and the pair peaks at 337.72 eV (Pd 3d 5/2 ) and 343.01 eV (Pd 3d 3/2 ) might be attributed to that of Pd2+ [45]. The calculated mol ratio of Pd0/Pd2+ in Pd5/ZrHP is 0.62. It was found that the binding energy of Pd 3d 5/2 and Pd 3d 3/2 in RuxPdy/ZrHP increased slightly with the added amount of Ru, and the calculated ratio of Pd0/Pd2+ increase continuously. In addition, the deconvolution of Ru 3p in Ru5/ZrHP catalyst (see Fig. 3(c)) also presents two pairs of peaks, Ru 3p 3/2 (462.13 eV), Ru 3p 1/2 (484.90 eV) and Ru 3p 3/2 (464.01 eV), Ru 3p 1/2 (486.92 eV), respectively, which belonging to the chemical states of Ru (0) and Ru (IV) [46]. Notably, the binding energy of Ru 3p 3/2 and Pd 3p 1/2 in Ru0.5Pd4.5/ZrHP decreased slightly as compared to those of Ru5/ZrHP. These shifts could be ascribed to the slight charge transfer between Pd and Ru or the formation of Ru-Pd alloy [38–42]. AC-TEM images and corresponding line-scan EDS analysis disclose that Ru-Pd alloy disperses evenly on ZrHP, and most observed particles size in 0.5–3.5 nm (see Fig. 4(a) & (b)). The calculated average particle size of Ru-Pd alloy in Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP catalyst is 1.9 nm, which is close to the crystalline size calculated in XRD (see Table 1). High-resolution images further disclose that those particles possess distinct atomic arrangement with the lattice spacing of 0.210 and 0.320 nm in a and c direction, respectively (see Fig. 4(c)). And this lattice structure and atomic arrangement fits well with the standard Ru0.03Pd0.97 alloy (the red ball is Ru and the blue one is Pd) in Inorganic Crystal Structure database (see Fig. 4(d)) [41]. These results confirm that Ru-Pd alloy formed in Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP catalyst. At the same time, the corresponding HRTEM-mapping images also demonstrate the uniform distribution of Ru and Pd elements in Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP (see Fig. 4(e)). H2-TPD analysis found that mainly one desorption peak at about 245 °C was detected over monometallic Pd5/ZrHP (see Fig. 5), which could be attributed to desorption of H2 that adsorbed on Pd [42], and the calculated amount of adsorbed H2 is 100.3 μmol/g-cat. It is interesting to note that the hydrogen desorption peak shifts to lower temperature and the amount of adsorbed H2 increases continuously with the added amount of Ru in RuxPdy/ZrHP. These results indicate that Ru-Pd alloy is more active for the adsorption and activation of H2 [47], which might be contributed to the electron transfer from Ru to Pd. According to the amount of adsorbed hydrogen, the dispersion Ru-Pd alloy in RuxPdy/ZrHP were calculated and summarized in Table 2. It is found that the addition of Ru to Pd could increase the dispersion of Ru-Pd alloy. Fig. 6 compares the Py-IR spectra of ZrHP and Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP. The characteristic adsorption observed at 1450 cm−1 was ascribed to the coordinatively absorbed pyridine on Lewis acid sites, and the band at 1540 cm−1 was ascribed to the protonated pyridinium ion on Brønsted acid sites [48]. These results confirmed that both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites formed in ZrHP. It was also found that the adsorption at 1540 cm−1 in Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP decreased slightly compared with that of ZrHP, which might be attributed to that the loaded Ru0.15Pd4.85 alloy could make partial Brønsted acid sites occupied. 3.2 Catalytic Reaction Table 3 summarizes the performance of Pd5/ZrHP, RuxPdy/ZrHP and Ru5/ZrHP for the hydrogenation of phenol. It is found that Pd5/ZrHP is selective for the formation of cyclohexanone and the selectivity of cyclohexanone reaches 99.3%. This performance is similar as that reported in literatures [16–18,49], which might be attributed to that the dissociation of phenol to phenoxy is more favorable on the surface of Pd [5–7]. But the activity of monometallic Pd is low, and the calculated turnover frequency (TOF) of surface Pd is 204 h−1 with a 20.5% conversion of phenol. On the other hand, the conversion of phenol over Ru5/ZrHP reaches 100% under the same condition, unfortunately, mainly cyclohexanol formed in the reaction mixture. It is quite interesting to note that small amount of Ru can increase the activity of Pd obviously, and the detected conversion of phenol increases continuously from 20.5% (over Pd5/ZrHP) to 55.3% (over Ru0.05Pd4.95/ZrHP), 97.9% (over Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP) and 99.2% (over Ru0.5Pd4.5/ZrHP) under the same condition. What is more important, the selectivity of cyclohexanone remains 99.1% over Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP. These results disclose that Ru and Pd or Ru-Pd alloy exhibit a synergistic effect for the hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanone as they can combine the high activity of Ru and the excellent selectivity of Pd. And the calculated TOF of surface metal in Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP reaches 785 h−1. The conversion of phenol increases slightly over Ru0.5Pd4.5/ZrHP catalyst, but the selectivity of cyclohexanone decreases sharply to 43.7%, which might be attributed to the strong hydrogenation ability of Ru [50,51]. Table S1 compares the performance of Ru0.15Pd4.85 alloy on different supports for the hydrogenation of phenol at 100 °C and 1 MPa initial pressure of H2. It is found that mainly cyclohexanone (rather than cyclohexanol) formed during the hydrogenation of phenol over all tested catalysts. The conversion of phenol and the selectivity of cyclohexanone over acidic supports (Al2O3, ZrHP and HBEA) supported Ru0.15Pd4.85 alloy are higher than that on basic supports (MgO, CaO). The promotion effect of acid sites might be attributed to that phenol is more easily adsorbed on the acid sites of the supports in the form of "non-coplanar", which can accelerate the hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanone [27]. On the other hand, acid sites can decrease the activation energy for the addition of adsorbed H from the metal to phenol [7,21], inhibit the further hydrogenation of cyclohexanone to cyclohexanol and/or facilitate the isomerization of cyclohexanol to cyclohexanone [28]. These results indicate that acid sites and Ru0.15Pd4.85 alloy play a synergistic effect for the selective hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanone. In order to make the prominent performance of Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP well addressed, the product distribution at varied conversion level of phenol with twofold amount of phenol (40 mmol) in feed is shown in Fig. 7. It is found that mainly cyclohexanone (>99.5%) formed at the beginning of the reaction (at a 10.8% conversion level of phenol, 0.5 h), and the selectivity of cyclohexanone remains higher than 95% even at 88% conversion of phenol (2.0 h). But cyclohexanol (with a selectivity of 9%) appeared at prolonged reaction time (2.5 h), which might be attributed to the deep hydrogenation of cyclohexanone. These results confirm that cyclohexanone is the primary and dominant product of phenol hydrogenation over Ru-Pd alloy, and cyclohexanone could also be hydrogenated to cyclohexanol at prolonged time. Reaction conditions: 40 mmol phenol, phenol/metal= 880, 20 mL cyclohexane, 1 MPa, 100 °C. Fig. 8 presents the performance of Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP for hydrogenation of phenol at different temperature with enlarged amount of phenol (40 mmol) in feed. It is found that the conversion of phenol is 36.8% and the selectivity of cyclohexanone reaches 99.4% under low temperature (100 °C). The conversion of phenol increases rapidly to 66.4% (120 °C) and 88.0% (130 °C) with raised reaction temperature, and the selectivity of cyclohexanone remains high than 98.0%. Though the conversion of phenol increases when further raise the reaction temperature to 140–160 °C, the selectivity of cyclohexanone decreases heavily to 89.3% at 160 °C. These results indicate that higher temperature could accelerate the deep hydrogenation of cyclohexanone to cyclohexanol. Reaction conditions: 40 mmol phenol, phenol/metal= 880, 20 mL cyclohexane, 1 MPa, 1 h. Fig. 9 presents the performance of Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP for hydrogenation of phenol under different pressure. It is found that the conversion of phenol increases continuously from 19.2% (0.5 MPa) to 36.8% (1.0 MPa), 70.2% (1.5 MPa) and 99% (2.0 MPa), and more importantly, the selectivity of cyclohexanone remains higher than 93% even at 2.0 MPa. And the highest turnover frequency (TOF) of surface metal in Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP at 100 °C and 2 MPa reached 1605 h−1. Further increase the H2 pressure to 2.5 MPa promotes the deep hydrogenation of cyclohexanone (as phenol was converted completely). Similar phenomenon was also reported in literature [52] because cyclohexanol formed mainly via the tandem hydrogenation of cyclohexanone over Pd-based catalysts (see Fig. 7). Reaction conditions: 40 mmol phenol, phenol/metal= 880, 20 mL cyclohexane, 100 °C, 1 h. The performance of recycled Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP at low conversion level of phenol with enlarged phenol in feed is shown in Fig. 10. It is found that the selectivity of cyclohexanone remained higher than 98% in all experiments, while the conversion of phenol decreases slightly from 36.8% (in 1st usage) to 36.0 (in 5th recycle). XRD patterns of spent Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP and its fresh partner are compared in Fig. 11. It is found that spent catalyst and fresh one exhibit similar structure, and the calculated particle size of Ru-Pd alloy only increases slightly from 1.8 nm (in fresh sample) to 2.0 nm. At a high conversion level of phenol (with phenol/metal = 440 in feed), Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP can maintain its performance in 5 cycles (see Fig. S1). These results indicated that Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP could be recycled for the hydrogenation of phenol. At the same time, the performance of Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP was compared with those published works in recent years in Table S2 [53–63]. It was confirmed that Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP exhibited excellent activity even under high phenol/metal in feed. Reaction conditions: 40 mmol phenol, phenol/metal= 880, 20 mL cyclohexane, 1 MPa, 100 °C, 1 h. In order to verify the versatility of Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP catalyst, hydrogenation of different phenol derivatives was carried out and the results are summarized in Table S3. It is found that most phenol derivatives could be converted to ketones with the selectivity higher than 96% at 120 °C within 1 h. But those diphenols and cresols need longer reaction time (2 h) to realize an equal conversion level. It might be related to the steric hindrance effect. Meanwhile, it was found that those substrates with -Cl electron-absorbing group have a lower ketones selectivity (about 92%), which might be attributed to the change of electron cloud distribution caused by substituents. In this case, the active hydrogen attacked those substrates easily, resulting in an increase in the amount of alcohol byproducts and a decrease in the selectivity of target ketones. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, it was found that ZrHP and it supported Pd, Ru or Ru-Pd alloy could be synthesized in a microwave-assisted method. Characterizations indicated that small amount of Ru can promote the dispersion of Pd or Ru-Pd alloy in RuxPdy/ZrHP, and the electron density of Pd or Ru-Pd alloy increased slightly with the addition of Ru. AC-TEM analysis further confirmed that well-structured Ru0.03Pd0.97 alloy formed in Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP catalyst. Catalytic reaction results disclosed that Ru-Pd alloy exhibited a synergistic effect for the hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanone as they can combine the high activity of Ru and the excellent selectivity of Pd. The selectivity of cyclohexanone over Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP remained higher than 93% even at a complete conversion of phenol at 2.0 MPa, 100 °C and phenol/metal= 880 within 1 h. And Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP catalyst could be recycled for 5 times. CRediT authorship contribution statement Zixuan Wang: Investigation, Methodology, Formal analysis, Writing – original draft. coredata.dc:description: Selective hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanone is a vital step in the manufacture of fiber (nylon), which is currently carried out over expensive Pd catalyst with low productivity. In this work, a series of Ru-promoted Pd catalysts were synthesized in a facile microwave-assisted method and tested in the hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanone. It was found that small amount of Ru in Ru-Pd alloy can increase the conversion of phenol obviously without loss of cyclohexanone selectivity. The selectivity of cyclohexanone over Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP remained higher than 99%, while the conversion of phenol increased from 20.5% (over Pd5/ZrHP) to 97.9% at 100 °C and 1 MPa. And the highest turnover frequency (TOF) of surface metal in Ru0.15Pd4.85/ZrHP at 100 °C and 2 MPa reached 1605 h−1. Characterization results revealed that the addition of Ru can improve the dispersion of Ru-Pd alloy and enhance its electron density. In addition, the activated hydrogen on Ru-Pd alloy and acid sites in ZrHP played a synergistic effect for the selective formation of cyclohexanone from phenol.
coredata.dc:title: Selective hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanone over small amount of Ru-promoted Pd/ZrHP catalysts
